section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Ss, Ff, and Pp Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will review the letters Ss, Ff, and Pp.

section-block.rac_body-text: Sing “Down by the Bay.” Emphasize the rhyming words such as whale and tale. Invite children to suggest additional rhymes to sing.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Ready, Set, Build! written by Meg Fleming and illustrated by Jarvis.
Pablo the Parrot loves rhyming narratives about two friends building together!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are the dog and the bird building together?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What animal characters do you see on this page?
I see the letter P in the word pack. What sound does the letter P make in the word pack?
What do you see on these pages? What is the dog sketching?
pages 6–7
The words space and race rhyme. They have the same ending sound. Now, listen as I read the next page. Which words rhyme?
The dog uses lots of tools to build. Who can point to the hammer? I wonder what a crane is. Who thinks they know? Now let’s turn the page to find out.
There’s the crane! Who can point to it on the page? What do you think the crane is lifting?
The words shingles, windows, and roof are clues about what the dog is building. What do you think it is?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are the dog and the bird building together?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to respond.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: a home for the dog and bird

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud a short sentence describing how we build things as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the dog and bird building together?
The dog and bird are building a h________ . (house)
The dog and bird are building a house.
How could you tell what the dog and bird were building?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Repetition is a key to children learning new letters. Point out frequently occurring letters and expose children to printed text as much as possible. Even allowing children to explore texts independently is good exposure.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Empathy
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion with children about a time they felt sad or hurt and someone helped them to feel better. What did that person say or do? Explain that we can show empathy for others by noticing what they are feeling or what they need. We can ask others what they need or we can do something kind. When we help others feel good, we feel good, too!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use our empathy Mind Builder as we revisit the book Ready, Set, Build! written by Meg Fleming and illustrated by Jarvis.
Clifford loves stories about characters who help one another.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages in the story where we can use the empathy Mind Builder to help us understand the characters and the story.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the word build in the title. Who can come up and point to the word build with me? As we read, let’s think about why it’s great to have the help of a friend when we build something. (MB)
The dog is smiling and playing on these pages. What does that tell us about how the dog is feeling? (MB)
How do you think the dog and bird feel about making a plan together? (MB)
How do you feel when you get to eat lunch with a good friend? How do you think the dog and bird feel as they eat lunch together? (MB)
pages 18–19
How are the dog and bird helping one another on these pages? (MB)
page 20
Who is the house for? Why do you think the friends want to share a house together?

section.rac_body-text: Tell children they will pretend to be the bird and dog. Have children work with partners to show empathy and use new vocabulary in conversation. The first partner asks, “Do you need help?” The second child should answer with something from the book, such as, “Yes, I need help lifting this rock.” Encourage them to answer using a word from this week: sketch, plan, build, lift. They can act out how the bird and dog help one another.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about why they build things. Encourage them to use the new words.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that teaching and practicing empathy in the classroom helps to develop this trait in children. (Cotton, K., n.d.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about things they do to stay safe in the classroom when they build or make things, such as using scissors and building materials carefully.
Sing “The Alphabet Song.” On the second round, point to individual children to sing a specific letter. Challenge the class to see if children can complete the round.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread the narrative Ready, Set, Build! written by Meg Fleming and illustrated by Jarvis.
Pablo loves that all narratives can teach us things, even make-believe stories!
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the dog and the bird stay safe while they are building?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think a hard hat and boots will keep the dog safe while building?
The dog must lift the box carefully. Let’s pretend to lift something carefully!
What does the dog wear to stay safe while cutting? What do you think the goggles protect the dog from?
How is the bird protecting its ears? What is the bird protecting its ears from? Let’s pretend to protect our ears!
Which words rhyme on these pages?
The book says “Tomorrow’s work is twice as fun.” Look at the pictures for clues. What do you think the dog and bird will do tomorrow?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the dog and the bird stay safe while they are building?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to describe and write about why they build things. Encourage them to use new words they learned about building this week.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the dog wear to stay safe?
The dog wears a hard h____ (hat) to stay safe.
The dog wears a hard hat to stay safe.
What are some other ways to stay safe while you are building?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Every vocabulary card includes an Act It Out step and a photograph to help multilingual learners—indeed, all students—to access the vocabulary. Additionally, you can model and have children act out vocabulary words when possible. These multiple approaches are particularly helpful to children with limited English proficiency.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about how different kinds of building materials are good for different things. Would marshmallows or blocks work better for building a tall tower? Why? Explain that if one kind of building material doesn’t work, children can switch to another kind to see if it works better. Being flexible and trying new things helps us solve problems and have fun!
Introduce two new words about building materials.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Three Little Rabbits. It is a narrative about three rabbits and their houses.
Pablo loves to read narratives about animals building things.
Ready, Set, Build! and The Three Little Rabbits are both stories about animals who build things. Let’s see what’s the same about these two texts!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
Why do we build things?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Idea
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did the first rabbit build a house with? What else can straw be used for?
What did the second rabbit use to build a house?
Which words rhyme? Which of the three houses do you think will be the strongest? Why?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Review Make a Prediction Strategy Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happened when the wolf blew on the house made of straw? What happened when the wolf blew on the house made of sticks?
Which building material worked best: straw, sticks, or bricks? Why do you think that is?
How is this story and Ready, Set, Build! alike? How are they different?

section.rac_body-text: Distribute three different kinds of building materials that promote fine-motor development—such as blocks, sticks or straws, and clay—to small groups. Invite children to build a house. Explain that if one kind of material or building idea doesn’t work well, they should try something new.
Provide a prompt about building, and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Good motor skills are considered important for children’s physical, social, and psychological development. Building with materials such as blocks and clay is not only fun, but also helps to develop children’s fine-motor skills. Encourage them to experiment with different kinds of materials to help develop fine-motor movement and control.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to imagine they are builders. Ask them what they would like to build. How would they build it? What materials would they use? What tools would they use? During the conversation, encourage them to use this week’s vocabulary and other building vocabulary they have learned. Then, invite children to put on their imaginary hard hats and get to work!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Ready, Set, Build! by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Jarvis.
Pablo loves to build and likes reading narratives about characters who build things! Narratives are stories that authors make up in their minds.
This week we read stories about building things. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What steps does the dog folllow to build his house?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s act out the things the dog does to get ready for his building day. Let’s put on our hard hat, put on our boots, and pack our lunch!
Why do you think the dog makes a sketch before he starts to build?
Now the dog needs to guide the backhoe. Let’s pretend to guide the backhoe to move the load of dirt.
Time for lunch! Let’s stretch out against the tree and pretend to eat together.
Let’s buckle up! Why are seat belts important?
Show me how you can climb a ladder like the dog. Up to the roof! And back down safely.
Our work day is over. Time for bed! Show me how you curl up in bed after a busy day.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What steps does the dog folllow to build his house?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write details about something they like to build. Then share their work!

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the dog do first?
What materials does the dog use to build?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that retelling stories helps children with comprehension and retention of information. Add modeling and movement to make the retelling fun and even more effective!
